div.p: LONDON, Printed for Iohn Guy at the Sign of the Flying Horse between St. Dunstan's Church, and Chancery Lane. 1680.

div.head: To the much Honoured CHARLES FOX, Esq.
div.p: I Very much congratulate this occasion, though I readily acknowledge, that this poor Present brings small advantage to any, but him that gives it; who gains thereby the opportunity of publickly owning those great respects he shall alwayes pay your name, and of setting his hand to a paper, as a voluntary surrendry to you, of all his good Wishes, and Services. If the Treat he provided be not so well drest, or serv'd up, as it ought to be, pray let him beg pardon, with that common, yet necessary excuse of a young House-keeper, one not well settled, and scarce with any thing in readiness. Suppose his Garden newly planted, very little, or no fruit to be expected the first year, and the unexperienced Planter, not as yet well skill'd, in keeping off the cold winds, and nipping Frosts; howsoever he intreats you to receive what he has rais'd, and to eat kindly of his first-fruits, with which the greatest men have been alwayes pleased, and Heaven claims them before other off rings.

Now dear Sir, as I once lov'd you with your other Brothers, so those hopeful Gentlemen being dead, I will center my good wishes on you; may you joyn their virtues and sweetness to your own, may you be one for all, to your Relations, and Friends, and may you like your excellent Father, be as eminently concern'd in the World, and as honourably prais'd by it, to the great satisfaction of

closer.signed: Your most humble Servant, L. Maidwell.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: WHo dares be witty now, and with just rage
Disturb the vice, and follies of the Age?
With Knaves and Fools, Satyr's a dang'rous fault,
They will not let you rub their sores with salt.
Else Rose-streets Ambuscade shall break your head,
And life in Verse, shall lay the Poet dead.
Since therefore such unequal Iudges sit,
Who for suspicion punish men of Wit,
'Twill be self-preservation to be dull,
It cracks the credit but preserves the skull.
Henceforth live long and undisturbed lives,
Your Countrey-Worships, and your tawdry Wives,
The flaunting Punk and Ladies eldest Son,
All such who are by mutual crimes undone;
Like Lakes look green and flourish to the Eye,
But yet for want of stirring putrifie.
For I am told that Fop, and eke the Clown,
Iointly subscribe Petitions in each Town,
And swear all Satyr with bold truth shall down.
Why, cry they, What has wit to do with me?
With this Mans folly, or his knavery,
It is not fit we lose our property.
We'll pound the Poet up in small extent,
Far from his arbitrary Government.
Birth-right is birth-right, and he shall not rail,
We are undone, if common sense prevail.
Meum and tuum now shall be the rule,
The Magna Charta for the Knave and Fool.
Therefore the Poet that designs this Treat,
Ventures to serve up light and innocent meat.
And since high season'd sauce don't well agree,
Excuse a strangers plainer Cookery.
For to extreams you do the Poet drive,
And make him leave his best prerogative.
So the poor Beaver lest he prove a prey,
Bites off his dearest part, and throws away.

div.head: ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Antonio and Circumstantio. Ant. waking and rising from his Couch.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: BLess me, Circumstantio, how goes the day?

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Dear Sir, two hours precisely are roul'd off since the Meridian, and Sir by the way I have often thought the Sun a proper emblem of all us, though we be never so glorious for birth or parts, like him alas how soon we set! 'tis pity noble Sir that men of parts—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: — Again Fool brushing up your thredbare phrases▪ your nasty ends of Gold and Silver, your tawdry intellectual Wardrobe, you had best tell me what's a Clock without your foolish sentences and morals— Thou everlasting Coxcomb, are not words to express thoughts by, and the plainest expression of our meanings best?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Oh Heaven Sir you amaze me! plain speaking!
Sure words were meant for ornaments of thoughts, and I'd not for the Universe be without those tropes, and flowers that my discourse adorn.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Most excellent Rogue! flowers? no your weeds rise thick, and I will root out them or thee, thou gross nauseous Fool: laughter which first thou tookest as an applause, since it hath been the cause of thy disease, shall be thy cure, and thou shalt be a scorn to all the Family.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: The envy, not the scorn, no men of parts can laugh at me

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In short Sirrah, tell me plainly what's a clock, or I will cudgel you most excessively.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Sir, the Sun has from its Zenith these two hours declined.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Incorrigible wordy Rogue!— Come Sirrah, I'll stop those Rhetorick vapours— Ho there within Pietro, is the Pillory I bespoke for this Fool made?

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: It is Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let it be brought in.

sp.speaker: Pietr.
sp.p: It shall Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Now Sir you shall find the ill success of translating the florid Coxcomb. Is there but one sort of Fool more nauseous than other to me, (I mean your Orator) and must you copy him?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Sir be concise and clear, I hope you mean not me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In short, most eloquent puppy, you must stand in the Pillory, expos'd to jeers and taunts of all the house, until two hours precisely are rowl'd off.— Sirrah, I told you the next trope was Capital, no metaphors but in turn'd suits Fool.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Oh utinam nescirem literas— the Pillory for Rhetorick and good parts!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: There is no remedy, I have often threatned you before.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Oh cruel master whose heart is hard as Rocks of Adamant!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Within there, bring in the Pillory, I'll try if punishment will reform thee.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I'll dye a martyr Sir to tropes and figures, Oh Nick— Nick Machiavel thou Enter with pillory. hast well observed, great merits when they rise too high, meet hate from them who ought to recompence them. Consider Sir the injury you do your own fair Honour, alas I shall not be hurt.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I'll try that, put him in.

sp.speaker: Piet.
sp.p: Come, come on.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Be not so temerarious, Friends.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Put him in, he's at his tropes still.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Must I abandon eloquence?— Certes thou wast not born of Humane race, but sprung from some wild Numidian Father, and got on some rough Caledonian Mother, from Ganges West, to Gades East, there is not one so savage. Hold, Hold, I say—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Welcome my dear Marcello thou art come in good time to see my Farce.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What Engine's this?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p:
'Tis a Collar for my Orator, you have often known him plague me with his tropes; this Rascal serv'd me all the
while I studied at Padua, where (instead of Learning) the Coxcomb got a little false Rhetorick and Pedantry, he affects to talk like a Scholar, and never since would bring a message or tell what's a clock without a trope.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: 'Tis pity you should affro●● one of such parts, release him now, I'll be his surety.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: He's incorrigible.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Sir, when for this noble intercession I shall cease to offer the oblation of my thanks upon the Altar of my heart, may I become the scum and scorn of vagabonds.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You see his amendment. [Enter Nuarcha. Dearest Nuarcha, I am your humble servant, let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Thank you dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What news from my Mistress the Widow Paulina?

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: This night she ends her year of Widowhood, and now will see and speak with man again, she has removed my old Masters statue out of her Bed-chamber, and old Seignior Paulo has leave this night to speak with her, but sure she is designed for one more young, of whom she thinks and talks, sleeping and waking.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Much thanks for thy goods news, faith I must kiss thee again, though much against my conscience and my appetite.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: How soveraign a Cordial is Mankind!

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Sir I beseech you to entreat for a remission of my ignominious censure.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Pray release your Orator on his submission.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I do upon condition he will abandon tropes and figures, and speak sence to his fellow servants.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: My affairs call me home, I had almost forgotten, Mrs. Lucinda, Seignior Paulo's daughter, whom you know her Father has placed with my Lady, has a desire to speak with you in the Garden about the prevention of her Fathers marriage with my Lady, which would much prejudice her affairs, I will make way for you to see her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You will most infinitely oblige me, assure her I will not fail to do her all the service of my life, and should think my self happy to venture it for her. One kiss more, dear sweet Mrs. Nuarcha.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p:
A most absolute compleat fine Gentleman, a civil
proper young man is a most sweet Creature! Sir your most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your servant.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: You are a most vigorous man to be able to kiss this Succubus.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This salacious old Chamber-maid is better bribed this way than any other.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You have a lusty mind to the Widow I see, that you can travel through so soul a way to her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: O Marcello, 'tis not the Widow which I aime at. Lucinda's Mine of beauty far exceeds the Widows wealth, so excellent, so sweet, so rare a Creature, I but pretended passion to the Widow to get access to beautiful Lucinda, and now congratulate my happiness, she has contrived an interview her self. But why do I tell thee of this? thou art an Heretick, an Infidel to love.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Oh thou mistak'st me, dear Antonio, I am a Convert, I have the Image of a fair one stampt upon my heart, that ne're can be effaced.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: This is news indeed, may I know who this fair one is?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: That adds to my confusion, she is unknown; yesterday morning going to my devotions, this Lady being near me dropt her Handkerchief, I stoopt and gave it her, she hastily put up her Vaile, and with so sweet an aire thank'd me for my service, and show'd me such a face, that nature in all her plenteous store can never shew an equal.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: The shewing of her face in Florence, is an encouragement against despair.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I should have thought so, had not I found when she perceived I watched her she shun'd my search, and spight of all my diligence avoided me in the crowd at Church, so that the shewing of her matchless face appears an accident from her surprise, and no designed favour.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It cannot be, you construe it amiss, fear not she'll give you opportunity again to see her. But as you are my Friend I have a thing of near concernment to relate to you, a thing that grievs me much, I find the Duke's command has not yet power to tame Lorenzo's spirit, he seems yet more enraged than ever.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p:
I know it since the Duke checkt him so severely, and
vow'd to punish his disobedience if he contracted not a friendship with me; he thinks that I by a complaint caused his disgrace, and is more bent upon revenge for that.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: It is a custome too frequent, and too brutal here, for Parents to entail their Quarrels with their Estates.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: It is so, and therefore I'd avoid them. Our Fathers ambitious of preferment could not admit superiour or equal, they liv'd like the two fam'd Theban Brothers alwayes in war, the fierce Lorenzo when but young was sworn to oppose the Growth and Fortune of our house, hatred was left by Will and Testament. I have used all healing wayes, affecting the friendship of a person that but for this, would be most worthy of it, but 'tis all in vain.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: A Messenger from Padua, who by his haste may well be called a Mercury, well figur'd by his wings on Head and Feet, is much sollicitous to impart his grand affair unto your proper ears.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Again at tropes, thou odious Rogue?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: Antonio Fare thee well, I will to Vespers, and see if I can find my unknown Mistress out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Farewell Marcello, I see this Love will make thee very devout. Where is this Messenger?

div.stage: Enter Julia and Leonora her Governess in the Town.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Madam, do not thus blast your beauty with your sighs
And drown it with fond tears, forget the cause
Of this dire mischief.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: As soon a wretch with dislocated limbs
Might put the rack out of his memory
That caus'd his torments. How just is heaven
To punish thus the Brothers unjust rage
With hopeless love upon the Sister! Fierce Lorenzo
Still more and more pursues the good Marcello
Hurryed by my Fathers hot spirit, and
His own mistakes and Jealousies, whil'st I
Doat on Marcello's generous nature, which
Would pass by all his crying injuries,
And heal the wounds which weaken both our Families.
At first I but admired his lovely form,
His vertue now compleats the victory.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Why do you call yours hopeless love? Marcello
Though yet he knows you not, has seen and loves you,
By yesterdays good signs you saw it, which
I'm too skilful not to understand.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Ah Leonora, should my Brother know
He once hath seen my face, although by chance,
He'd tear my heart out, but did he know
I lov'd him! Oh fatal eyes that ere beheld
This lovely enemy.

sp.speaker: Leon.
sp.l: Yet were you married to Marcello, his courage
Might defend you from your Brother and perhaps that marriage
Would close the breach between the Families.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: 'Twould pull down ruine on us both.
I see thou know'st not his ungovern'd rage.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Too well I know and fear it, he is talking yonder
In the Piazza, should I suffer you to loiter thus
In the way to Church, I should soon feel his rage I fear.
Let's hasten to Vespers, devotion and good musick
May perhaps soften your care.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: No Leonora, no divinity can justle out Marcello
From my thoughts.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Come Charge, let's hasten to the Church,
The Saint of this day whatever good he
Does, brings us good Musick. All the Masters
In Florence assist at the Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Yet all will cause but little harmony
In me, there's nought but discord in my thoughts.
Oh fatal love! yonder is my Lorenzo,
Heaven! my Lorenzo, foolish tongue he ne're
Alas can be so, though he long has warm'd
My tender heart, and yet he never saw me.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What are you musing on? let's haste to Church.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He'll hate the Sister of his enemy,
His rage does burn so fiercely in his breast
'Twill cause eternal separation
'Twixt him and any of our Race; fool that
I am, that I should like that fierceness
In him too, and think it does become him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: What do you mutter to your self? go on.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I find my love too hard for me, when we are
Bewitched to love a man, we like
Each fault, and folly in him too.
Bless me! my Brother and he come
Towards one another! stand by, I'll
Wait the sad event, I shall be known
By thee, else my black habit makes me
Undistinguish'd, and I would try to hinder it.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I'll not appear.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Retire, I'll venture on an odd experiment.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: What's here my Brother and Marcello!
Oh fatal meeting. Retire Leonora and let
Mealone—

div.stage: Enter Lorenzo and his man Vincentio, and Marcello with his man Albricio.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who's here, my hated Foe? now for his
Blood, what power has hitherto defended
Him from this Arm and Justice?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: So I shall have an honourable occasion
Of shewing my prowess.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I will avoid him as much as honour
Will permit me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: What dost thou shun me, Coward?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am less a Coward than thou a Brute,
I fear thee not thou know'st it,
But I'd obey the Duke.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: That name calls all my strength into my arm
And quickens my revenge, you have abus'd me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis false.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: At thy life.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou ne're shalt reach it.

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.l: Sir I will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Your servant Sir.

div.stage: Julia goes to Marcello and Camilla to Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Oh hold your hand, spill not Lorenzo's
blood,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My life, my soul, my Genius, my good Angel
In appearance, but my destroyer now.
Am I a Rival to my enemy?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Is your protection there?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis in my hand.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O Sir, If ever prayers could move your fierce
And stubborn nature, hear 'em now,
Pull not Marcello's blood upon thy head.
He's Generous and would forget your injuries.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: He dare not then remember 'em, prithee
Woman let me go.— Come from thy guard
And fight.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Hold, hold, the rashness of this act will ruine you.
Behold my tears, deny 'em if you can.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Ha! who art thou?
By heaven the brightest thing that e're was seen,
What is't shrinks up my nerves, and calls
Back my revenge?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I on my knees beseech you will desist
From your rash action, can you deny me?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By all the Saints in heav'n I cannot.
Death what's this that softens me to
Woman? By heaven and earth she is
The sweetest Creature that earth e're was,
Or heaven e're made.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Who is't that on her knees can beg for my
Marcello? have I Rivals too besides the
Enmity of our Family to undo me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ah Madam had the care you have express'd
Been aim'd at me, I had been blest enough.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: I had a care of you, but he must be my care.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Marcello go and live, this Lady bids thee
Live. Thank her.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank none but heaven for my life,
It is unmanly to be thus vain-glorious.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Good Sir walk this way, I have something
More to say to you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Who are you Madam that have hindred
This present quarrel between my mortal Foe
And me, but let me tell you, y'have 〈◊〉
My private peace, and raised a war more
Dangerous within me than any thing I
Could have met from him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I dare not tell my name, I meant no
Harm to you, but if you love your self,
Or if your nature has imbibed
But the least softness from your Mothers milk,
Pursue not farther good Marcello's life.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Good Marcello! Hell and Furies! she loves him.
First let me know who gives me this command.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: First Sir, deserve it by your temper,
And be assured I will not be ungrateful▪
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Tempests and whirlwinds! whither am I rapt!
She is gone, she has lest me quite unmann'd,
At once I am stung with love and jealousie,
And I have let my Rival scape my fury.
Sirrah, dog that Lady, and on your life
Enquire out who she is.
Thou art not my Foe alone but happy Rival.
Instead of cooling shor has inflam'd our strife:
I'll first defeat thy love, then take thy life.

div.stage: The Scene discovers Paulo leaping with his Doublet off.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p:
In troth 'tis well leapt, Paulo, who can say thou'rt old, let me see any young man leap with more agility— hah well done Paulo, come thy joints are plyant, thy back lusty, and thou fit for an able Bridegroom,— hah well done again honest Paulo. What? grey hairs are no marks of old age, but of many years, of chaste and sober youth, and of no idle expence of life, of no years cut off by a Chirurgeon, nor washt away in a Tavern. Widow I commend thee in thy first choice, and hope thou wilt resemble it in a second— Have at thee Widow, have at thee.— Now well jumpt Paulo. But now I must fatherly infuse Chastity into my Daughter, and teach her rules too hard for me, Declaim against the lewdness of the World, and advise her to chuse the vertue of a Nunnery,
for the being 〈◊〉 setled, my Widow can assault me with no very strong objection. Lucinda come hither.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I come Sir.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: What have you been doing Lucinda?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir I have been observing the Pictures in the long Gallery.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Which of them Child?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I observed Europa and Iupiter, and the Picture of Calisto surpriz'd by the same amorous God.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: And we observed how he put a trick upon Danae, for all the Guards of her severe Father.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Out upon it, meer bawdry, dost thou know my Child the moral of it? it declares a hot Gallant, and a vile Governess debauch't with money to ruine her charge: Out upon you naughty Girle! to indulge your Carnality with provocation; why did you not look upon the good Saint Mary Magdalen, you know she bemoan'd all her love-vanities, you should have viewed St. Katharine of Alexandria. Did not I bid you speak to your Lady to take down these Pictures, and that of Mars and Venus in a net?

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: O Devilish dissembling old Fellow!

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: I will be a kind Father in keeping thee spotless from this world, I am now old, and can best tell you the small improvement vertue makes in Worldly conversation; come, have you considered well my Child our late Discourse about a Nunnery? Oh the sweet life! O the blessedness of such retirement! O divine pleasure of a Nunnery!

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: This old Goat thinks to deceive me. What sure do you propose most unnatural rules to be observ'd by her in the fresh spring of her life, which you cannot submit to in the frozen December of your age?

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Peace vain naughty carnal Woman. Speak Child, does silence give consent? perhaps thou may'st through piety be Canonized: O what joy! and what honour to us all! to have posterity after thy death pay devotion to St. Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray Sir, may not Wives be Saints? if you please I will turn Nun when I am a Widow.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: I well said Madam; Pray have you the heart to put a young Woman of this neat shape, this complexion, these bright eyes, this sweet breath, these clean teeth—

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Woman, hold thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: I will not, what into a Nunnery! what flesh and blood dares be her Confessor? there's ne're a shav'd pate of them all but has more mind to her than a month's fasting.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: O Lord! she will make me deaf with talking.

div.stage: [He walks disturb'd and she follows him.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Had she been crooked, had she wanted an eye, one leg shorter, one hand revers'd, or uncurable fits, or by any distemper improper for copying out her own sweet-fac'd Picture: then she had been fit for a Nunnery, then most fit for your Matins and Vespers.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Well, have you done?

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: No Sir, I have not done, Is this flesh and blood for a Nunnery? no, she shall be a Matrimonial Saint, her shrine shall be a Down-bed and a Quilt, and her Chapel a well furnisht Chamber, the Pilgrim that shall kneel to her and kiss her, shall be a young handsome man, and you need expect no Miracle, but to see her Nuns work run up and down, and call you Grand Pappa.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: I tell thee Woman, I shall chastise thee if thou holdest not thy tongue. Thou hast been false, thou hast corrupted my daughter, thou hast confederated with Carnality: Get thee out of my sight, I will forthwith speak to my Lady Abbess about it, and she shall be admitted to morrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, if you please, since a Daughter cannot with a Father dispute this great affair, which like marriage is for better for worse, let your Friend and mine reason it calmly, whether your only Daughter should turn Nun; If their reasons convince me, I obey.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Well, for once I consent, who shall they be?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, any young Gentleman of Florence shall judge for me, and for you my design'd Mother-in-Law Paulina.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Begon you sawcy Baggage: What, concern your self in your Fathers Business? what, you can prate, can you disobedience?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
No Sir, I am all duty; you told me, you lov'd me, because I did resemble my Mother: I would fain increase your
love, and be like my Mother in every thing.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Begon I say, my will is fixt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pray Sir, I ever lov'd my Father, and since the world is so perillous, let us both leave it: You often commanded me to follow my Parents Example.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Hence Impudence. And get thee out of my presence, Thou pestilence of the Family: [Exeunt Luc. and Nuar.— pert Slut— Well now for my Widow— Well jumpt Paulo— hah vigorous Paulo, hah lusty Paulo— Hah brave Paulo.

div.head: ACT II.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: WEll sirrah, what makes you stay so long, when I bid you return a speedy answer from Lucinda?

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Pray Sir, let me excuse my stay, secundum quid, by the History of some extraordinary contingences which interfer'd, though indeed I am of the Stoicks opinion, that nothing is contingent, but only seems so quoad nos.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Sirrah to the purpose Rogue, Rascal.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Sir, why do you wrong your self, and debase your nature by this vile imploy, which instead of making you red with anger, should make you blush for shame?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You tormenting Villain speak now, or else I am resolv'd to damn you to the Pillory.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Alas Sir, the Pillory! by this passion you extinguish every thing that is Socratick, or indeed Philosophical; you become my servant, I can make you kick me when I please, alas poor Gentleman! did he but see how passion alters his countenance, and defaces the pleasure of his Mistress!

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Within there-bring in the Pillory; now sirrah you shall not escape: bid your fellows come in with the Pillory and Garland.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Sir, pray ponder the thing, and that you may not by designing me, expose your self to domestick ignominy, I will endeavour to give verbal satisfaction.

div.stage: Enter Pietro, Cook, Butler, Coachman, with the Pillory and Garland.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Look invincible fool, here is the best Scheme for your Rhetorick, this must be your Climax, and this the ornament for your florid head, come put his Collar on, lest in his madness he bites some of you, and so infect you.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Fellow-servants intreat your Master to consult his reputation, and not pursue a thing so mal a propos.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Insufferable slaye, as impudent, as invincible.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Sir, what Errour, what fault, what transgression? where is the least Circumlocution? though habits are very tough.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: In with him. I leave him to you, let him not sleep, for that's bad in Physick, I allow you all battering instruments; sirrah, your faults are many, I hope they will reckon them up in my absence.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Torrens dicendi copia multis, & sua mortifera est facundia.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: What at it again? I hope this punishment will prove a cleansing vomit for your tough bits of eloquence.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: I will suppress my anger, though it swells my heart, and hear what the dull Rout will say, and thus by taciturnity deceive them. Philosophy I thank thee!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Lord what makes Circumstantio in this strange disabilie as he used to call it! he swells like some Don in his ruff, sure the rogue has got a cold and cannot stir his neck.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: No, no, the Landress has put too much starch in his Cravat: that light pate of his peeps like a Cork out of a bottle.

sp.speaker: Coach.
sp.p: Well learned Domine! I knew you would at last be yoked for your frequent breaking of hedges, most high and mighty, you were alwayes despising your fellow-servants, calling the Cook greasie, Butler frothy, the Coachman stable man.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: I am afraid our sport will be prevented by the coming of this old Maid, now must we kiss her, and talk of her husband, to keep her in some tolerable humour. Come Gentlemen show your breeding.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Blessings on you all, kind hearts, I have not received so much comfort these two months: pray where is Antonio? for I came to speak with him: ah! but what do I see the accomplished Circumstantio in the Pillory?

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: Ah how dark and erroneous are the sentiments of the unphilosophick, which proceed from want of definition and distinction, they suppose this Pillory to be malum verum, which we that have been better taught know to be but malum apparens, no wise man can suffer ill; for how insignificant is malum poenae, when the essence of a man is free from malum culpae! Oh what consolation do I find in Metaphysicks! I will assure you Auditors, neither candid, nor gentle, that I value not this Pillory nor its Pilloreity.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Well, I never heard him speak so finely before.

sp.speaker: Pietro.
sp.p: Mrs. Nuarcha, my Master is coming.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Then I will compose my self. Sir, Mrs. Lucinda so desirous of your company [Enter Ant. has sent me after your servant to hasten your coming, and to tell you that she expects you within an hour at the Garden door, where I shall be ready to receive you, and for this good news let me beg Circumstantio's liberty. Indeed Sir you do not use him according to his deserts.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Indeed Mrs. Nuarcha you are in the right, but for your sake and this excellent news, I will not at this time be ungrateful in denying you any thing, well let him come out; Circumstantio you're bound to pay your respects to this Lady, and by right, if she thinks fitting, to marry her that brings you the reprieve, but as the Prologue of Matrimony, kiss her.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I kiss her not quà Nuarcha, but quatenu● my deliveress.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Your words and lips shall alwayes be acceptable.

sp.speaker: Antonio
sp.p: I must now return, shall I tell Lucinda that you will not fail, for she expects me with impatiency.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Tell her I will watch each minute, and the hour will seem a year till I wait on her.

div.stage: Enter Julia and Governess, presently after Marcello, and his Servant, in the Town.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Madam, Marcello just meets us.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: — If he
Knows me I am ruin'd, is there no way
To escape him? though I would willingly
With his leave fly into his arms.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: — Come, come
Prepare your discretion to receive him.
And put him off with hopes of seeing him,

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, though in obedience to your command
I durst not enter the Church after you,
So nice you are of discovering your self,
Yet now be not offended if I strive
To know the name of my kind Protectress.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sir, pray retire, for sure the fierce Lorenzo
Hovers hereabouts to meet you, and then
I his fury returns, as sure it will,
Perhaps the kind Lady that bow'd his heart
And arm, may not be at hand to help you.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Like Heaven you gave us unexpected help,
And speak your mind like it in Oracles,
Dark and mysterious. I know no Lady
Neither you nor her, and owe no safety
To any but your self. Strange interview!
Big with contraries, which saves, and yet destroyes.
To hinder my chance of death thrown
From my enemy, yet as the same Friend
To murder me by kindness to my foe!

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Let it satisfie in this place in words
To promise you, that I am as ready
As the other Lady to render my
Assistance to the worthy Marcello.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: It seems you know me Madam.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: — Not so well
As the Lady who ventured the blind rage
Of Lorenzo, by exposing her life
To save yours, you have small reason to blame
My hard heart, when you find such softness there.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis the greatest severity
To rally with a Wretch upon the rack.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Come, you must be kept there till you confess.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Confess! what Madam?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: — The name of her that
Did you such service, and then you may more
Justly expect mine, for my part I can
Allow you but one Mistress at a time.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Madam, if you design me by cruelty
For death, let me not mistake some kindness
In your words to keep me longer in pain.
Oh speak my fate, for doubt is worse than death.
You'll prove unkind if you pronounce my death,
Yet more kind by speaking to finish life and pain.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Sure despair is the worst vice of the Brave.
Well, to be short, I will make
This agreement with you, pursue no more
Questions nor any further inquiry
At this time, and I promise suddenly
To grant the satisfaction you desire.
And may Heaven grant that knowledge don't increase
Those torments which we both conceive in ignorance.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Well, I submit, 'tis more generous to say, I obey my
Mistress, than necessity, and 'tis better far to stand still, than
march after love, when it moves like a wandring fire.
Lest the poor Traveller goes more astray
In a blind Moonless light, and unknown way.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Sure my Servant is lost, as well as his poor Master. Oh how I rack my mind to know who this fair Creature is! perhaps to my greater torment, for some small hope hovers about me in my ignorance, which will take wing and upon information leave me [Enter Vincentio. Well, who is she? speak— hold— upon your life forbear, your look foretells misfortune.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Pray Sir, shall I tell you, or shall I not tell you?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: If your relation be good, stay not a moment, but if fatal, let it remain in everlasting silence— yet I must hear, come who is she?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Nay Sir, be not so passionate, for I can neither kill you, nor save you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Slave be quick, who is she?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Pray Sir be satisfied, heaven and St. Peter knows for me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Wretch, dost thou not know? why dost thou keep me thus in pain? speak or for ever hold thy tongue, who is she?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Sir, in short I dogg'd her, but she was too nimble for me, she was mingled with so many in the Church, that I could not distinguish her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Villain thou lyest. I will kill thee, and write fool in thy blood, what, not distinguish her? villain thou lyest, 'tis impossible, a bright circle alwayes crowns her face, her vail was all illustrated, as clouds gilded by the Suns darted beams, her breath would discover her at distance, as spices in blossom betray Arabia to approaching Travellers. Roses grow for ever where she treads, and nature paints her footsteps: not know her, not distinguish her! Impudent sot; recollect, and tell me you know her.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Hey-day: here's brave alteration in my Master: truly Sir, to speak the truth, I have a great cold, and so perhaps could not smell her, and then my eyes are very weak, and cannot look against so much light; as for Roses I saw none. Ladies servants, and their servants servants look not with the same eyes. Perhaps 'tis alwayes Summer, and hot weather when you see her, but it was Winter by that time I drew near to her.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Yes, by your stay it seemed so; march before, and lead me to her; or—

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Lord Sir, what do you mean? have a little patience, and she may come by this way again. Vespers were almost done when I came to you: 〈◊〉— see your enemy Marcello is just going into his house.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I would it were his grave, but I will shortly send him or my self thither.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Sir pray look that way— I think I spy the same Lady coming, yes 'tis she, now I see the light about her face, yes I smell the roses, and see them blush, and peep under her Petticoat.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p:
'Tis she— I know my murdress is at hand by inward bleeding. My heart beats vehemently, and my blood presses
with haste through lifes flood-gates: love which animates all creatures, abates my courage, when I have most need of it. I cannot speak to her, and yet I must.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Lorenzo is here, alas I tremble
To meet the Man I love. I know he stares
To learn who I should be, and where I live.
'Tis only ignorance can make him kind,
For knowledge would extinguish his devotion.
He comes this way, be sure you discover
Nothing of me to his servant.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Madam
Grant me the favour of some few minutes,
To tell you that you have kill'd me, and sav'd
My enemy; pray pardon the roughness
Of my unpractis'd love, born in a storm
And yet wrapt up in its clouds and darkness.
Oh tell me I beseech you who you are,
That were so kind to my foe Marcello.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sir, I should venture more to save the life
Of good Marcello; and since time and place
Hinder me from offering long prayers
To you, let me beg one boon on my knees
If you can love

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Madam, I beg of you
Not to abuse you supplicant; O Death!
She names the villainous Marcello with affection,
And calls him good, but in death I should be
Charitable, pray name your boon that I
May grant it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: May good heaven bless Lorenzo
For this mercy; be kind to Marcello
And then—

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Curst expression! each syllable
Proves a poynard, and stabs me to the heart.
Marcello is my rival; Dear Madam
Pronounce those words again to make me happy,
If there be happiness for me in death.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Come Charge, let us go.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Hold, hold, you have not proved your self a woman yet, and discovered who your Lady is.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: But you have declared your self a Serving-man by that question, What are you? your masters forlorn hope? sent out to skirmish with the enemy, and then retreat to the main body.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: I never heard the Sutlers wife, or the Laundress call her self part of the Army before.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Saucebox, I believe your empty belly, and foul Linnen put these words into your mouth; come Charge let's go and not expose our selves thus in the street.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I go with great regret, but must retire,
Farewell Lorenzo, and be kind to me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By heavens I am astonished and scarce know
Where, and who I am! O stay a little
And hear my last petition, pray tell me
Who you are, so cruel to Lorenzo
And so kind to your Marcello; Whom now
I must for ever hate, for what can move
A man so much, as his lost fame and love?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: O speak not such ill omens, for kind heaven
Will bring us safe out of our labyrinth.
I go Lorenzo, but will soon find time
To see you, and make my self more happy,
If now you'l promise me to retire
Without observing me.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Well, I promise
Since it pleases you, to torment my self:
And be tormented by my ignorance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: 'Tis best, for knowledge would my hopes destroy,
His hatred is so inveterate against any of
Our house: farewell Sir

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: Farewell my Visionary Mistress; for I neither know who, nor whence thou art; like Ixion, I did fancy a Goddess, but embrac'd a cloud. Sirrah what were they we discours'd with just now?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Two Women, without doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: 'Tis false, impudence, are your sure you talked with any woman?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: I am sure mine was a true Woman, by her way of speaking.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: 'Tis strange that I should thus forget my self, to lay open my follies before my servant: hurried with new passions of love, and jealousie. Marcello is my Rival and my Foe. My Rival— 'tis enough— it is decreed. I will forthwith to his house, and kill him: no place shall save him, not the Court, nor Duke; nor Houshold gods; no bright apparition shall rescue him from death the second time.

div.stage: Enter Marcello and Camilla in their house.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Brother, are you resolv'd to go to night?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes Dear Sister, my horses are ready.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: When shall I see you again?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: To Morrow.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I am sorry you go; pray have a care
Of your self. Lorenzo you know is much
Enrag'd, and seeks after you

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: — Fear nothing
Sister, Lorenzo is honourable.
His greatest fury can suggest nothing
That is unworthy of a Nobleman.
To day I met him, and I will tell you
At more leasure what wondrous providence
Diverted his rage, and divided us.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My Brother little thinks, I know the thing
So well, which he pretends to hide.— But yet
Brother, last nights dream disturbs me. Methoughts
A young Gentleman of that house kill'd you,
And I in just revenge stabb'd Lorenzo.
Ye both ●ay dead upon the groud, and then
Rose up, and like the dearest Friends embrac'd.
But that must signifie the other world.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Dreams are but the Echo's of the thoughts
Possess your mind by day.— a lively mark
Of your great concern for me, for which I thank
My loving Sister.

sp.speaker: Alb.
sp.p: Sir, Lorenzo whom I never saw here before, with angry looks and hasty words, bids me tell you that he must speak with you.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: Oh my Brother!

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: 'Tis fortunate Sister to have him here, I hope he comes prepared to hear me speak: retire Sister, whilest I introduce him.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: I will withdraw, but overhear you both.

div.stage: Marcello going to the door meets Lorenzo.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Lorenzo most welcome, you oblige me
And my house for ever, by this favour.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Marcello you mistake, I hate both you,
And your loath'd house. I desire no welcome,
But come hither like thy evil Genius
To terrifie thee, and bid thee meet me
In such a place, where chance shall not part us.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: I cannot fear it in Lorenzo's shape,
Who rather should command my love, than fear,
If he could bridle passion, and 〈◊〉
His better reason, and the Dukes command.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Oh thou Rock under smooth waters! thou shalt
Never deceive me, thou base enemy,
Best able to kill at distance, and to
Murder me by whispers.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: You wrong me much,
I hate the wretch as much as you, who can
Deserve this character. I would in my
Own house be calm, and make my plea
To these false objections.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: — as true, as thou art false.
Now I find in thee a vice, I ever
Thought thee free from, I mean base cowardise,
Which springs from guilt; thou understand'st my rage,
And its just cause, yet would'st by oily smoothness
Loosen my hold, if thou hast any heat,
I will raise it by the remembrance
Of thy Mistress, who sav'd thee from my revenge
Today, 'tis her I'll have too, yet that
Shall never buy my friendship.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: 'Tis enough,
You have broke for me all ties of honour,
And good manners. Lorenzo, be gone,
My house is your best defence, pray leave it,
Your last words will force me to imitate
Your rudeness.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I will not go without you,
I came to fetch you out, and punish you.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: It is in vain by calmness to flatter
His proud insolency any longer.
I have been tame too long, and that my wrong'd
Love and honour may have their quick revenge
Upon thee, beyond the reach of casual
Assistance to save thee, name some secret place
Where we may meet, if thou dar'st come,
Early to morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Marcello
For this kindness, if I find it real,
I must thank thee: in nothing else thou can'st
Oblige Lorenzo— well— by Sun-rising
Tomorrow, let us meet at the great Oak
In the Neighb'ring Forest, till then— Farewell.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Let not my passion spoil civility,
I will see you safe out of my own doors.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Forbear your ceremonies, I hate them
From you, like him that uses them, it seems
As recantation of your former words.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: You might accept them now, for I will shew you none to morrow. I dare not tell my Sister what has pass'd betwixt us. [Enter Camilla. Here she comes, I will prevent her questions by telling her my story first; Camilla I am glad that all things will be soon compos'd between Lorenzo, and my self; for he came very kindly to propose a conference to morrow, where we shall upon the debate grow more calm, I hope for ever; and that my propos'd affair may not hinder me, I must take my leave, and be gone. Dear Sister Farewell, and wish me good success.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.p: May all that is good preserve my dear Brother. He's gone, and now my eyes shall freely speak the rest. He thinks he has deceiv'd me, and that I did not over-hear their fatal assignation, I will retire to my Chamber, and consider how to save them both.

div.stage: Enter Paulina and Lucinda in a Garden.

sp.speaker: Pauli.
sp.p: Lucinda, your father is so brisk and vigorous of late, that he seems to have dropt Twenty years of his life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes Madam, he has been fortifying himself these three months to my knowledge, that he might appear brisk upon this day of admission.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Prithee pay more respect to the old Gentleman before your Mother-in-law, he alwayes appear'd cheerful though not to this degree.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well Madam, if you have a mind to be my Mother-in-Law, 'tis you will have the worst of it, not I.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why so merry Cousin?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Because after a very little time my Father must return to rheum and spitting-sheet, and then how will you away with it? I love an old man well enough for a Father, but not for a husband.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: Pray Cousin let us reason it, such an old man as your Father, or my late husband, would make you an excellent match, come think of it Lucinda, it might prove most proper, his gravity to allay your levity, his cold your heat, as we correct Wine with Water.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Out upon it! I would not have an old man, though he made me a joynture of the Indies, though he built me a house of Silver, and turn'd a rich stream of golden Tagus to wash my garden walls, though he could afford me Cleopatra's draughts every morning, I should find out another Antony.

sp.speaker: Paul.
sp.p: O brave Girle, had you rather venture a young mans frolicks?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, rather than to lye by an old man, 'tis lying with a Coffin, and I am sure you had rather lye by a certain young man than my father.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Why do you think so Cousin? an old man is a very wise bosome friend, whom long use of life has polish'd, from whom you may learn the wisest rules to methodize your self.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Very good, you advise me to marry an old man, that is to say an history incarnate, true Annals writ upon a Skeleton; and what then, go to bed with this rotten Chronicle? no he shall lye cover'd with Cobwebs first. I don't intend to embalm matrimonial mummy, to spoile the Apothecary's trade, and fill my Closet with gally-pots.

sp.speaker: Nua.
sp.p: Madam, Seignior Paulo desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Well, I will go wait upon my Cousin, 'tis to give my approbation to the design of his musick he presents us with to night at Supper. Cousin farewell, and think more charitably of an Old husband.

sp.speaker: Nuarc.
sp.p: Antonio is just come to the back door, and I have got my Mistress luckily away.

sp.speaker: Lucinda.
sp.p: Pray bring him into this walk pray make haste, and I will give you the best gown I have.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: I go, I go to serve you both.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I know there is no danger of the Widows marrying my Father, though she carries it so demurely; she has a greater longing after my dear Antonio, and my love is not without some hope; for though he seems to court the Widow, yet his looks and words may be as well interpreted to me, I wish my supposition proves true.

div.stage: Enter Antonio with Nuarcha to Lucinda.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Madam, this happiness you confer upon me is more than any past or future service can repay: pray Madam let me know the honour of your commands, that I may express some thanks by readiness to obey them.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Sir you shall know them presently, they concern both you and my self: good Nuarcha, oblige me in observing my Cousin and Father's motion, that I may not be surprized talking with Antonio.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Well, dear heart, I will, I go most willingly, for a hundred to one but they will talk about my Mistresses affection to Antonio, which amorous discourse will so heat my desires, that they will exceed moderation: well goodly Couple Farewell, I dare trust you both.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ah Lucinda, give me leave to speak, and whilest there is time to undeceive you, by all that is good you should believe: you are the design of my true love, and the Widow but the Shadow of the Picture to cheat the eyes of the beholder.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Antonio, you mistake, I am not she you mean, I am Lucinda and not the Widow, 'tis she has ever had the appearance of your love by words and actions, which bid her judge it real. But I wish with all my heart he means what he speaks.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Let this propitious hour be for ever blest, in affording me time to express my heart.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Well, well, you are a merry man to whet your discourse on me, against my Cousins coming.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Madam, do you think I want eyes and ears to distinguish the beauty, and wit of Lucinda?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But to be serious, the only way to procure your Widow, is by keeping off my Father; who to speak dutifully of him seems in the Autumn of his life to pretend a second Spring: I will assure you your Rival is very brisk with her; therefore pray Court your Widow to the purpose, and give her greater assurance of you, that my Father may be diverted from clapping me into a Nunnery; and that is the end of my giving you this trouble. Would to God I could tell him plainly that I love him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh Lucinda, be not so cruel as to condemn me to new pains: for this falshood of pretended love is as great a torment to me, as a mistake in you; rather command me to own my love before your Father, and the Widow.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: No, pray Court on, upon discovery Lucinda must forthwith march into a Nunnery, I believe you will hardly free her from it without her Portion.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dearest Lucinda do not think so basely of your Lover, that the spirit of his love so much delights in dross and earth. I love not Lucinda as the Heiress of her Father; but for the inestimable dowry of her Virtue and Beauty: I have enough left me by my Ancestors, and fortune would be prodigal, to grant me Lucinda to command me and it.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: These words will make be believe former passages, that he is real, I must confess. [aside.— Well, you are a pleasant man, yet I think it would prove better for me to think of a Nunnery, and its happy quiet, than of launching into a troublesome world, and Domestick Employment, if it were not for one thing—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What is that Lucinda?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Why it must out— if it were not for— my Antonio.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Oh pronounce those blessed words again, lest it passes for a dream of happiness.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Nay, I am glad 'tis out, but if it had not been for fear of Nunnery and Hair-cloth, I had held out longer: yet you
must Court the Widow, as you used to do, the next time you see her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: For heaven sake do not relapse, I am weary of the cheat: I must acknowledge the truth, this unkindness suggests as if you did not love me; for Lovers like the Deity hate to have their dues offered to an Idol.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But as you love me, continue it for a while, I warrant you for some handsome Plot to discover all in a little time.

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Madam, your Father and my Lady are coming, pray set your self in order.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: How now! what do I see? is not that a young man, and that my daughter?

sp.speaker: Nuar.
sp.p: Yes Sir, and a handsome young man too, he happened to come by when the Garden door was open, and being delighted with the beauty of the place, I invited him in, as one not unknown to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Paulin.
sp.p: Good Sir be disturb'd at nothing, he is a Gentleman of my acquaintance, I am glad that any thing here has obliged his stay: and that my Cousin was here so luckily to entertain him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Madam, I need not fear to come off in the old Gentlemans opinion, having so good an Advocate.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Umph, Advocate, and old Gentleman! no more old Gentleman than your self, for years do not bring age, but debauchery of youths and such Jacks as you are. Come Sauce-box, can you jump as I can? come, the old Gentleman, as you call him, shall try your activity.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: How zealously this old Gentleman, like some sort of lovers, acts one thing and is another, declaiming against youth, yet mistaking its gayety!

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Young fellow there— leave off your prating, and try if your back can bear jumping as mine does: prethee sweet Widow don't mind his prating, but observe this tryal of skill.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Pray Madam, speak to my Father to have a care of straining.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: How is that, you Saucy baggage? abuse your Fathers back to his face, that was one cause of bringing you into the world? get you gone you undutiful slut, to abuse the spring of your being.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Madam, what must your influence and virtue be, which can thus change nature, and metamorphise old age into brisk youth?

sp.speaker: Paulin.
sp.p: But the victory is greater which conquers the stronger, and set●les wandring youth within the sober bounds of constancy.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Come troublesome Companion, if you will have all prating and no jumping, pray leave this Lady and prattle with that young Flirt there. I'll warrant her I shall punish her within few dayes for impiously throwing dirt upon my back.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Madam, since at this time this old Gentleman will be your only Guardian, pardon me if I am forc't to play the hypocrite.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Well Rag-manners forbear your flouting, or you shall take what follows. And be satisfied that this Lady is otherwise disposed of.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Lucinda, it certainly foretells good luck that I have so easily obtained your Fathers consent to Court you.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: But what would become of us if either of them imagined the plot betwixt us?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Faith, I will directly discover it.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes, yes, throw me into a Nunnery▪ and then see how you can get me out: pray at this time break up company, lest it seems too much familiarity at first sight, I will contrive to see you again before midnight.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, I will obey you in all things— Madam I must beg your pardon for my rude intrusion, and yours Antient Sir, if I have given you any occasion of trouble.

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: Well Sir, we thank you as much for your room as your company— Antient say you?— Widow pray give him his farewell.

sp.speaker: Paulina.
sp.p: Antonio, I am sorry my circumstances will not permit me to discover how much I value you: but be assured that you shall be alwayes welcome to any place, which calls me Mistress.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Madam, your most obedient Servant, I wish I might in this place plainly express the truth of my affection. With your Fathers good leave Lucinda let me be esteemed your most faithful Servant.

sp.speaker: Paulin.
sp.p: Paulo, what think you of him, is he not a most accomplished Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Paulo.
sp.p: No, no,— very indifferent,— a meer flash, come put him out of your head. Let's go in, the air grows cold.

div.head: ACT III.
SCENE I▪
div.stage: Enter Marcello, Circumstantio in the Town.

sp.speaker: Circ.
sp.p: MY Master has I must confess above my merits honoured me with a Commission to wait upon you and kiss your noble hands, the which Province I embrace with an eminent Exaltation of joy, since you are a person of such illustrious honour that Florence scarce contains your equal, I am sure not your Superiour, which is no small symptom of my Masters piercing wit and more distinguishing Judgement, that have made so Excellent a choice.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.p: You'll never leave your Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: The subject needs it not, your vast merits afford so ample a Field of Discourse, that with Excessive pleasure I could wander in those delightful paths, but at the present I am too strictly bound by my Masters too hasty expectation of my too quick Return.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prithee to the point if you be in haste, for I am so.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I shall be brief, for brevity, though I must confess it does too often obstruct the ravishing torrents of an eloquent▪ and charming tongue, yet in quick dispatch of business I hold it necessary, and therefore I shall proceed.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I must be gon else, what would Antonio have?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: You being a person strictly allied to him by firm necessitude, and bound to him by the indissoluble knot of an inviolable Friendship, and being a person to whom he is multis nominibus obstrictus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What would he have with me?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: He being also a person embarrass'd with an amorous Intrigue, well may I say embarrassed for res est 〈◊〉 plena timoris amor, as the Poet sings sweetly, But Antonio being a person—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: — That would speak with me, when and where?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I shall inform you, he being a person who not only having great proclivity to that amorous passion, but being driven by the violence of her beauty whose Image he wears upon his heart, she being a person—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: — Ounds is she a person too, nay then Farewel.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Hold good Sir, and hear the end.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: S'death you will never come to an end.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: She being a person—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: — I will not stay if she be a person.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I am astonished Sir at your impatience, would you have me speak vulgarly and abruptly, and in haste like a Nurse-keeper that is sent for Aqua-vitae?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am going out of Town, I shall return and wait upon your Master to morrow.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Hear me first, I shall be concise, for I am a person—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: — You a person? nay then farewel▪ a pox on your person.

sp.speaker: Albric.
sp.p: I am much mistaken Sir, if your unknown Mistress be not coming this way— and if it be she, I saw her come out of Lorenzo's house: She's here.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What do I hear? Madam I know your person.
And yet I know not what to call you,
Unless it be Lorenzo's Mistress.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Jealousie is sometimes a sign of great love,
But alwayes of little wit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I see then you will own it.
Has my so violent passion deserv'd your scorn?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Jealous and angry too! nay then I'm sure
You are fast enough i'th' toyle.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lorenzo has employed you then
To set your beauteous snares to draw me in.
Then prey on me. This is most exquisite revenge

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: You are confident I am Lorenzo's Mistress,
Because the Lady who spoke to him to day▪
Is yours.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: On my honour I know her not,
But I am sure, you came but now
Out of Lorenzo's house.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.l: Shall I not accomplish my Embassie to you?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pox on thee, begon Impertinent.— Albricio know the
Tools Message if you can find it out.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: What luck is this he should discover it—
I visited his Sister who was bred in the
Same Nunnery with me, and whom I love
Equally with my self.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If this be all, I may be happy yet.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Lorenzo is the man on earth I would not have,
I hate his stubborn and inveterate humour,
If he were sole Monarch of the Universe
I would not marry him, but if my too forward
Care of you will make you jealous, you
Shall have less of it hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O say not so, I had rather my good Angel
Should neglect me, and hover about my
Enemy.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Were there no other man in Florence, he
Should never have my love.
A Bark that's toss'd by Tempests on a Rock
Were safer than a woman cast on him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Dear beauteous vision, for yet I know not
What to call you, I am convinc'd
You would refuse his love, and were I sure
You would accept of mine.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: You are not sure I am worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Thou art worthy of the love of Princes.
The greatest Hero that the earth e're bare
In thee might meet the end of all ambition.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Suppose I were one of Lorenzo's Kindred.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wert thou his Sister, I would headlong fly
Into thy Arms, though he were at my back
Ready to give me the malicious blow
He long has wish'd me.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: How I admire and love his generous nature!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By this plain declaration I deserve
Thou shouldst reveal thy self, and make me happy.
For whosoe're thou art, by Heaven I swear
My life and love to thee shall end together.
I am sure thou'rt good, for nature would not slubber so
To place an evil mind in such a body.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Your Generosity has so oblig'd me
That the next meeting which I will contrive
As soon as may be, you shall know my name:
Let it suffice at present to inform you
My vertue is unquestion'd, and my birth
And fortune too may claim the good Marcello.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Life of my soul, here let me seal my vows.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.l: The Naturalists observe—

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.p: — What have I to do with your Naturals, what would your Master have with mine?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I am confounded, that I should draw my breath in so unlearn'd an Age!

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.p: Where is your Master?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I cannot say affirmatively what place does circumscribe him, I suppose you hold with Aristotle, that locus est superficies.

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.p: Pox on Aristotle, where's your Master?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Paulina's Mansion did contain him locally, for Corpus must alwayes be in loco, that's certain, but at this present point of time I can only say indefinitely he is not at home.

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.p: Farewell, a pox of this stuff. Sir, I cannot understand one Sentence that he sayes.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: I see Lorenzo coming up that street.
Now if you would have me believe one word
You speak: avoid him quickly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I am all obedience, Joy of my life farewell.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.l: Will you not lend your ears for one small moment?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Damn you impertinent Rascal.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.l: The world is envious of my parts I see,
There's no man truly honour'd while he lives.
I will write something, Quod nec Iovis ira nec ignis,
And then I'll dye and purchase true renown.

div.stage: Enter Camilla and Govern. in the Town.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Disswade me not, I am resolv'd to venture
Through all the dangers Cowards can imagine.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Consult your honour and my safety Madam
As gentle as Marcello is, he would revenge
Your love adventures upon me.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Fear not.
I will protect thee and defend his life,
Or perish with him, 'tis no time to 〈◊〉
With his or with my lov'd Lorenzo's safety.
I'll save my honour too, or lose my life.
Go to Lorenzo's house, and let him know
I am here to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Consider Madam.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I prethee lay thy tedious wisdom by,
We must have desperate remedies for this ill.
If thou'dst preserve my life, I do conjure thee
To do as I appoint thee.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Here he comes.
Put a strict guard upon your honour now
And let not love find out its weaknesses.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My honour's safe, he sees me not.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Revenge,
Thou art my Deity, to thee I pay
My vows and off rings, Oh curs'd Marcello
To morrows Sun shall see thy treacherous heart
Throbbing within this hand. Oh Heavens who's this?
My Genius come to stop the lawful rage
sp.stage: Cam. puts her self before him.
sp.l: Of this avenging Arm? It is her shape
The motion too of her Coelestial body.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: I know her by her Governess my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Fair unknown Saint of all my vows, to thee
The dear protectress of my life and fortune
I humbly kneel, and from thy powerful doom
Expect my life or death. If thou'lt be kind,
I will look down upon and pity Kings,
If not, the miserablest slave may pity me.

div.stage: Vinc. speaks to her Governess kneeling.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Fair unknown Saint of all my vows, to thee
I humbly kneel Protectress of my fate,
Put up this Cloud and shine upon thy servant.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Whose Fool art thou?

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: I am Lorenzo's, pray whose Fool art thou?
It is a secret I would gladly know.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: I shall never be thy Fool, that is, thy wife.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Break, break distracted heart, there is no cure.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Sir, you ask pity of me who needs it more.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Pray mock me not, such beauty stand in need
Of pity? 'tis impossible, you may
Give law to all that see you, and those wretches
That once could disobey you ought to be
Cast out from all humane Society,
And left to the company of Bears and Wolves.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Oh were these words the dictates of your heart,
I should be happy.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: By all the joyes of Heaven
They are, I swear on your fair hand, except
You intercede for vile Marcello's life,
There's no command of yours I'd not obey,
I'd singly stand a breach, leap into fire
Or mount a billow when the foaming Sea
Is most enrag'd with tempests: I for you
Would scorn all danger, but the loss of honour
I cannot bear.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Nor could I e're esteem
One that would hazard that; but to be just
And honourable, you should end this fewd.
'Tis the most brutal custome of our Countrey
For Families to fight they know not why:
Beasts are more civil, for they never quarrel
But for necessity of nature: Good Marcello
Is willing to contract a Friendship with you,
And would on that condition give his Sister
Who's young, and they who have seen her say she's fair,
And all conclude her rich and vertuous,
This Sister he would give in marriage to you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How! marry one of his accursed Race?
I'd sooner take one sick of the Plague and keep
My Nuptials in a Pest-house. There's no yoke
Which the most savage Tyrant could impose
I would not sooner bow my servile neck to.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Ah what hope
Poor lost Camilla now remains for thee!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: But for the life of base Marcello Madam
You are the most improper Orator,
Can a scorn'd Lover hear his cruel Mistress
Pleading for his successful, hated Rival,
And not be more enrag'd against him for't?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: He never yet by words or signs made love
To me upon my honour.— Heaven I fear
I shall reveal too much.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: It is too plain you love him. Oh Devil
With what patience can I reflect on that
And let him live an hour?

sp.speaker: Cam▪
sp.l: He has my esteem because I think him generous,
And he's beside a Friend to our Family,
My love he ne're shall have: But 'tis as plain
You have a Mistress who staid his arm from you.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: No Lady e're could touch my heart but you,
May Thunder strike me dead if e're I lov'd
Before I saw your all commanding beauty,
Which I am resolv'd to perish, or deserve,
If all the service of my life can do it.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: If you desire to make me credit you,
Meet not Marcello in the wood to morrow.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hah, has his fear made him betray the place.
And time of Assignation, where I was
T' enjoy my enemy? What riddle's this?
Can you be so concern'd, and yet not love him?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It is your safety Sir which I consult,
Make me not blush to tell the cause of this.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: If this be true, as I will ne'r distrust
The words so fair a mouth as yours shall utter,
Say but the cause is love, and tell me who
You are.— let my lips dwell upon this hand for ever.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: My birth and fortune equal yours,
My honour's yet unblemisht in a ●●ught.
If I can love a man on earth 'tis you.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Madam, this is too much, we must be gone.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Peace Screech-Owle, or by Heaven I'll strike thee dead
With Curses. Oh let me hear those Sacred words
Once more, that I may think I dream not.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: I have said too much to one who loves so little.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Little!— the vertuous love not heaven so much.
They know as little of it too, as I
Of you my Heaven.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Thou art as impertinent and as inquisitive with me as thy hot-headed Master is with my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Perhaps you may be as handsome, and I may have as much reason. Oh let thy splendid face break out upon me sweet, and I will be as full of raptures as my Master.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: You'l soon be satisfied, as for example.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: Benedicite, I am satisfied thou hast punisht me enough. By heaven a Succubus: Thou Scare-crow to preserve that goodly fruit.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.p: Sawcy fellow, I hope my face deserves better than yours.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.p: If e're I trouble thee with love again, maist thou confound me, and consent.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Grant me but this request, and on my honour
Next enterview which shall be suddain, you
Shall know my name.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: How is my nature lost, how soft I'm grown!
By heaven I cannot disappoint my enemy,
And yet by all the sacred powers above
I never can deny thee ought.— But yet my honour.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: False Braves alone are jealous of their honour,
The true are still assur'd they cannot lose it.
Or grant me this, or I'll conclude you love
So little, 'twill not be worth my seeing you again,
And I will ne'r attempt it.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Say not so.
My life, my honour, all I have is yours,
You shall dispose of all, and I'll obey you.
I will not meet him, though I had much rather
See him in opposition with his Sword
Than have the fairest Lady but your self
Within my arms in dalliance.

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Strange passion of revenge! and I'll not trust it.
I have another way yet to prevent their meeting.
Since you are pleas'd to promise you'll not meet,
I take my leave for a short space of time.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Why should we ever part?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: It must be now.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: First let me kiss thy hand, once more, again, again,
Why should I ever leave it?

sp.speaker: Cam.
sp.l: Farewell my good Lorenzo, I was saying Dear Lorenzo.
Hold, if you dog me, I'll never see you more.

sp.speaker: Gov.
sp.l: Farewell Todpool, Toad, Monkey.

sp.speaker: Vinc.
sp.l: Farewell Hag, Night-mare, Scarecrow, Mawkin, &c.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Heaven, with what pangs she leaves my soul!
That in its last flight will not leave my body
In half so bad.
Methinks she tears my heart-strings, as she goes,
I feel her pulling at'em. But what, have
I promised not to meet my enemy;
To lose my honour and revenge for one
I know not? I was not my self, my madness
Made it. Perhaps she may be one
That's prostituted to the vile Marcello.
By heaven I lye, it cannot be, she is
Divine, the Saints we pray to are not half
So beautiful, or holy.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Are you Lorenzo?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: Marcello sends you this, I lye, but 'tis no matter, I am well paid for lying, and I believe 'tis for pimping too.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.p: reads. My mind is changed, and I will meet this night at eight by the Great Oak in the neighbouring wood, 'tis Moon-light. If I hear not from you, I will conclude that you consent to it.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.l: What answer Sir?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: There needs none, there's something for you.
Lucky above my wishes,
I only promis'd not to meet to morrow,
I am free, and I will haste to my revenge.
Sister whither are you going?

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: No farther, I came to meet you at your coming in.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Iulia I have news for you.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: What's that dear Brother?

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: I have appointed time and place to meet
My mortal enemy Marcello, and suddenly
All our vexatious Quarrels will be ended.
I know the bravery of thy spirit makes thee
Hate that cursed race, and 〈…〉
With me.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: Heaven send a good end.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Do not distrust my courage or my fortune.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: When and where, is this meeting to be?
Oh my Marcello!

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Hah, she sighs, I must not trust her tenderness,
Inquire no more, 'twill not be long.

sp.speaker: Iulia.
sp.l: I see a paper in his pocket, perhaps it contains
The appointment: forgive my theft.
When e're you meet may heaven preserve my
Dearest brother.

div.stage: She embraces him and takes the note out of his pocket.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: Thanks my Iulia, let's in.

sp.speaker: Iulia
sp.p: reads. What's this? To night in the neighbouring wood by the great Oak. Heaven, how shall I find this out.— Hold, I shall be observed.

div.stage: Enter Antonio and Lucinda in Paulina's house.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Think Madam if Paulina discovers my deceit, how we shall be defeated, what e're my tongue may utter, my eyes will tell her plainly whom I love.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: We women are vain enough to interpret all to our advantage, as perhaps I do when I believe you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: To put you out of doubt, this night I will contrive your escape, and to morrow a Priest and you may make me happy, I have sent to my Friend Marcello to be in readiness, in hope that I might perswade you to this reasonable proposal.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Is it reasonable then to run away with a Gentleman at the second Interview?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Rather than to be ●lapt into a Nunnery before the third Interview.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis fit we should try mens tempers first, and what they can bear, be coy, and use them scurvily beforehand, for they are sure to use us so afterwards.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Our Italian Marriages are made for interest, but mine with you would be for love, and to assure you of it, I could wish you were a Beggar.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am like to be little better, if I marry without my Fathers consent, and he'll not give it because his paying a good portion to me may be an objection of the Widow against his Marriage.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ah Madam, I would have you come all love and no money into my Arms. Our Italian Ladies in love matters use to be so wise to consider that opportunities are but few, think of a perpetual prison, Hair-smocks, Midnight Prayers, lying on Matts alone, Green Sickness, and continual Chalk-eating.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: These are terrible things, and you being less terrible, I cast my self upon you.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My dear incomparable Lucinda!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: None of your raptures, those are alwayes short-lived affections, that shew themselves that way.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: My love is as immortal as my soul. [Enter Circ. Oh here's my Man, what news?

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: As soon as I had received the honour of your Command, I did forthwith repair with all the haste that was decent for a Florentine of that Gravity and Education that I pretend to, to the house of Don Marcello, which I soon found at that time did not circumscribe its Master: the noble Pater Familias being lately sallied forth upon some important affair, which at that particle of time urged his absence from his own Mansion—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Thou eternal Rogue, the presence of my Mistress saves thy life.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: But to proceed, departing from this Mansion almost in despair

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Rogue—

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Of any opportunity that might present itself of my encountring with the noble Gentleman to whom my Embassy was then addressed—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Villain—

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I applied my self to a more gentle and deliberate motion, uncertain where I should guide my wandring steps to the attaining of my wish'd for end.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Most eloquent impertinence!

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: And though I must confess with anxiety enough duly weighing the emergency of your occasions, yet I could not retain my self from reflecting with pity on the erring and illiterate vulgar: who wanting the unspeakable benefit of education and literature were little better than so many two-legg'd beasts wandring up and down within the several walks of this fair Urbane Forest.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dog, Rogue; incorrigible Rascal, there's a reward for your Damn'd Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Alas Sir, these unseemly blows do you more harm than me, in as much as they betray your want of Philosophy.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Again Villain.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Are these the Guerdons due to eloquence, which might most justly claim its wreaths of Laurel?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Of Laurel! wreaths of Indian Cane, which thus Sir I confer upon you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hold Sir, he is distracted, this is not the way to cure him, let him be bled and dieted.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: Is she barbarous too?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Madam, I ask your pardon for the rudeness his impertinence provokes me to; but sirrah tell me what Marcello said to you or by Heaven I'll kill you.

sp.speaker: Cir.
sp.p: I had indeed at last post varios casus, post tor dis●rimin● reru●, a vision of Marcello, but he whether possest with more important thoughts, or rather diverted by an encounter with a Nymph, who is a person—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well Dog, I shall not know, be gone and see my face no more.

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.p: Sir, I beg pardon for intruding thus upon you, but my Master not being able to find out your mans meaning has sent me to know what service you would command him.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Desire him if possible to put off his Journey into the Countrey to night: for I have a business of the greatest consequence in the world to me, which will require his assistance.

sp.speaker: Albr.
sp.p: I will tell him instantly.

sp.speaker: Cir.
